paragraph.content: section 34 (Authority may issue directions to telecommunications service providers);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 35 (Authority may impose financial penalties);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 36 (Authority may obtain information or documents relevant to investigation); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: section 38 (Authority may issue enforcement notice).

section.name: s45
section.heading: Immunity of Authority, authorized officers, etc.

subsection.content: No person to whom this subsection applies, acting in good faith, shall be personally liable for any civil liability or claim whatever in respect of any act done or default made in the performance or purported performance of any function under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The persons to whom subsection (1) applies are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Authority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any authorized officer; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any police officer or other public officer assisting the Authority or authorized officer in the performance or purported performance of any function under this Ordinance.

part.name: P6
part.heading: Unsolicited Electronic Messages (Enforcement Notices) Appeal Board

section.name: s46
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 6
section.def: Appeal Board (上訴委員會) means the Unsolicited Electronic Messages (Enforcement Notices) Appeal Board established under section 47(1);
appellant (上訴人) means a person lodging an appeal;
Chairman (主席) means the Chairman of the Appeal Board appointed under section 47(2);
Deputy Chairman (副主席) means a Deputy Chairman of the Appeal Board appointed under section 47(2);
legally qualified (具所需法律資格) means qualified for appointment as a District Judge under section 5 of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
panel member (備選委員) means a member of the panel of persons appointed under section 47(3);
presiding officer (審裁官), in relation to an appeal, means the presiding officer referred to in section 49 (composition of Appeal Board for purposes of appeal).

section.name: s47
section.heading: Appeal Board established

subsection.content: A board to be known as the “Unsolicited Electronic Messages (Enforcement Notices) Appeal Board” is established.

The Chief Executive shall appoint a legally qualified person to be the Chairman of the Appeal Board and such other legally qualified persons as he thinks fit to be Deputy Chairmen of the Appeal Board.

The Chief Executive shall appoint a panel of persons, not being public officers, whom he considers suitable for selection under section 49(1)(b) (composition of Appeal Board for purposes of appeal) as members of the Appeal Board.
A person shall be appointed under subsection (2) or (3) for a term of not more than 3 years but may be reappointed.
An appointment under subsection (2) or (3) shall be notified in the Gazette.
The Chairman, a Deputy Chairman or a panel member may at any time resign by notice in writing to the Chief Executive.

The Chief Executive may revoke the appointment of the Chairman, a Deputy Chairman or a panel member on the ground of incapacity, bankruptcy, neglect of duty or misconduct proved to the satisfaction of the Chief Executive.
The remuneration, if any, of the Chairman, a Deputy Chairman and a panel member shall be paid at a rate that the Financial Secretary determines.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Appeals to Appeal Board

subsection.content: A person on whom an enforcement notice is served under section 38 (Authority may issue enforcement notice) may appeal to the Appeal Board against the enforcement notice or any part of the enforcement notice.

A person who wishes to appeal under this section must lodge a notice of appeal with the Appeal Board not later than 14 days after the enforcement notice is served on him under section 38 (Authority may issue enforcement notice).

Unless ordered by the Appeal Board under section 51(1)(i) (powers of Appeal Board), the lodging of a notice of appeal shall not have the effect of suspending the operation of the enforcement notice or any part of the enforcement notice under appeal.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Composition of Appeal Board for purposes of appeal

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of an appeal, the Appeal Board shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a presiding officer, who shall preside at the hearing of the appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 2 panel members selected by the presiding officer.

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (3), (4) and (5), the Chairman or, if the Chairman so determines, a Deputy Chairman selected by the Chairman shall act as presiding officer.
The Chairman shall not act as presiding officer if he has a direct or indirect interest in the appeal.
The Chairman shall not select a Deputy Chairman to act as presiding officer if the Deputy Chairman has a direct or indirect interest in the appeal.

In the event that the Chairman and each Deputy Chairman has a direct or indirect interest in an appeal, the Chief Executive may select a panel member who is legally qualified and who does not have a direct or indirect interest in the appeal to act as presiding officer.
The presiding officer shall not select a panel member to hear an appeal if the panel member has a direct or indirect interest in the appeal.

If the term of appointment of the presiding officer or a panel member selected under subsection (1)(b) expires during the hearing of an appeal, the presiding officer or panel member may continue to hear the appeal until the appeal is determined.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Procedure on appeal

subsection.content: In the hearing of an appeal, every question before the Appeal Board shall be determined by the opinion of the majority of the members hearing the appeal except a question of law which shall be determined by the presiding officer, and in the case of an equality of votes the presiding officer shall have a casting vote.

subsection.leadIn: A party to an appeal shall be entitled to be heard—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the party is an individual, either in person or through a counsel or solicitor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where the party is an organization, either through a counsel or solicitor or through—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of a Hong Kong company or other company or body corporate, any of its directors or other officers;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a partnership, any of its partners; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the case of any other organization, any of its officers.

subsection.content: The Appeal Board may, if it sees fit, permit a party to an appeal to submit written representations to the Appeal Board in lieu of the party appearing at a sitting of the Appeal Board either in person or through a counsel or solicitor or a director, officer or partner referred to in subsection (2).

Every sitting of the Appeal Board shall be held in public unless the Appeal Board considers that in the interests of justice a sitting or part of a sitting should not be held in public, in which case it may hold the sitting or part of the sitting in private.
After hearing an appeal, the Appeal Board shall determine the appeal by upholding, varying or setting aside the enforcement notice and may make such consequential orders as it considers necessary.
The Appeal Board shall notify in writing the parties to the appeal of its decision and the reasons for the decision.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Powers of Appeal Board

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 52 (privilege against disclosure) and section 55 (privileges and immunities of Appeal Board members and witnesses), in the hearing of an appeal, the Appeal Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), receive and consider any material, whether by way of oral evidence, written statements, documents or otherwise, and whether or not it would be admissible in a court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by notice in writing signed by the presiding officer, summon any person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to produce to the Appeal Board any document that is relevant to the appeal and is in his custody or under his control; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to appear before the Appeal Board and to give evidence relevant to the appeal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: administer oaths and affirmations;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: require evidence to be given on oath or affirmation;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: make an award as to costs—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: against any other party to the appeal, if the Appeal Board is satisfied that in all the circumstances of the case it would be unjust and inequitable not to do so;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: where the Appeal Board is satisfied that it is just and equitable to do so, require a party to the appeal to pay the costs of the Appeal Board in hearing the appeal;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: make an order prohibiting a person from publishing or otherwise disclosing any material the Appeal Board receives;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: make an order prohibiting the publication or other disclosure of any material the Appeal Board receives at a sitting, or part of a sitting, that is held in private; and

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: make an order suspending the operation of an enforcement notice.

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(a) shall not entitle a person to require the Appeal Board to receive and consider any material that had not been submitted to or made available to the Authority at any time before the enforcement notice under appeal was served.
Costs referred to in subsection (1)(e) and (f) are recoverable as a civil debt.

The Chairman may determine any matter of practice or procedure relating to the hearing of appeals where no provision governing such matter is made in this Ordinance or in any rules made under section 56 (rules).

section.name: s52
section.heading: Privilege against disclosure
section.content: For the purposes of an appeal, the appellant, the Authority and any other person summoned under section 51(1)(b) (powers of Appeal Board) shall each have the same privileges in respect of the disclosure of any material as if the proceedings before the Appeal Board were proceedings before a court.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Case may be stated for Court of Appeal

subsection.content: The Appeal Board may refer any question of law arising in an appeal to the Court of Appeal for determination by way of case stated.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of the case, the Court of Appeal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: determine the question stated; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: remit the case to the Appeal Board, in whole or in part, for reconsideration in the light of the Court’s determination.

subsection.content: Where a case is stated under subsection (1), the Appeal Board shall not determine the relevant appeal before the Court of Appeal determines the relevant point of law.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Offences relating to appeals

subsection.leadIn: In relation to an appeal, a person who, without reasonable excuse, refuses or fails—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to attend and give evidence when required to do so by the Appeal Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to answer truthfully and completely questions put to him by the Appeal Board; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to produce any document that he is required by the Appeal Board to produce,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person who publishes or otherwise discloses any material in contravention of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 51(1)(g) (powers of Appeal Board); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under section 51(1)(h) (powers of Appeal Board),

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.content: It is a defence to a charge for an offence under subsection (2)(b) for the person charged to prove that he did not know and had no reason for knowing that the Appeal Board had made an order under section 51(1)(h) (powers of Appeal Board) prohibiting the publication or other disclosure of the material concerned.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Privileges and immunities of Appeal Board members and witnesses

subsection.content: The Chairman, a Deputy Chairman and a panel member have, in the performance of their functions under this Part, the same privileges and immunities as a judge of the Court of First Instance in civil proceedings in that Court.
A witness before the Appeal Board shall be entitled to the same privileges and immunities as if he were a witness in civil proceedings in the Court of First Instance.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Rules

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to provide for the lodging of appeals; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: generally for regulating the practice and procedure of the Appeal Board.

section.name: s57
section.heading: Claims for loss or damage

subsection.content: A person who suffers loss or damage by reason of a contravention of any provision of this Ordinance (the claimant) shall be entitled to bring proceedings against the person who committed the contravention.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), it is immaterial whether—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the contravention constitutes an offence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person who committed the contravention has been convicted of an offence in relation to the contravention.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (6), proceedings under subsection (1) shall be brought in the District Court but all such remedies shall be obtainable in such proceedings as, apart from this subsection, would be obtainable in the Court of First Instance.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of subsection (3), the District Court may, if it considers it fair, just and reasonable in the circumstances to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make a declaration that the respondent has committed an act, or engaged in conduct, in contravention of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall perform any reasonable act or course of conduct to redress any loss or damage suffered by the claimant;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order that the respondent shall pay to the claimant compensation by way of damages for any loss or damage suffered by the claimant by reason of the respondent’s act or conduct; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: grant an injunction or any other appropriate remedy, order or relief against the respondent.

subsection.content: By virtue of this subsection and notwithstanding any other enactment or rule of law, the District Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine any proceedings under subsection (1) and shall have all such powers as are necessary or expedient for it to have in order to provide, grant or make any remedy, injunction, order or relief referred to in subsection (4).

Where an amount claimed for loss or damage under subsection (1) does not exceed the amount referred to in paragraph 1 of the Schedule to the Small Claims Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 338), the proceedings shall be brought in the Small Claims Tribunal, and that Ordinance shall apply to the claim in the same manner as if it were a monetary claim founded in tort as referred to in that paragraph.
The Limitation Ordinance (Cap. 347) shall apply, with necessary modifications, to a claim under this section in the same manner as it applies to an action founded on tort.

For the avoidance of doubt, nothing in this section affects, limits or diminishes any rights, privileges, obligations or liabilities conferred or imposed on a person under any other enactment or rule of law.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Offences relating to misuse of information

subsection.content: No person to whom an unsubscribe request is sent under section 9 (commercial electronic messages must contain unsubscribe facility) shall use any information obtained thereby other than for the purpose of complying with the requirements of that section or section 10 (commercial electronic messages must not be sent after unsubscribe request is sent).

No person to whom any information contained in a do-not-call register is made available under section 33 (access to do-not-call registers) shall use any information obtained thereby other than for the purpose described in section 31(2)(b) (Authority may establish do-not-call registers).
A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 6.
A person who knowingly contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years.

It is a defence to a charge for an offence under subsection (3) for the person charged to prove that he took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Liability of principals, agents, employers and employees

subsection.content: Any act done or conduct engaged in by a person in the course of his employment (the employee) shall be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as done or engaged in by his employer as well as by him, whether or not it was done or engaged in with the employer’s knowledge or approval.

Any act done or conduct engaged in by a person as agent for another person with the authority (whether express or implied, and whether precedent or subsequent) of that other person shall be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as done or engaged in by that other person as well as by him.

In any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance brought against any person in respect of an act or conduct alleged to have been done or engaged in, as the case may be, by an employee or agent of that person, it is a defence for that person to prove that he took such steps as were practicable to prevent the employee or agent from doing the act or engaging in the conduct, or from doing or engaging in, in the course of his employment or authority, acts or conduct, as the case may be, of that description.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance brought against any employee in respect of an act or conduct alleged to have been done or engaged in, as the case may be, by the employee, it is a defence for the employee to prove that he did the act or engaged in the conduct in good faith—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the course of his employment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in accordance with instructions given to him by or on behalf of his employer in the course of his employment.

subsection.content: Subsection (4) does not apply to an employee who, at the time the act was done or the conduct was engaged in, was in a position to make or influence a decision regarding that act or conduct.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Liability of directors, partners, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Where an organization has done any act or engaged in any conduct constituting an offence under this Ordinance, the following person shall, unless there is evidence showing that he did not authorize the act to be done or the conduct to be engaged in, be presumed also to have done the act or to have engaged in the conduct—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a Hong Kong company or other company or body corporate (the company)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any director of the company who, at the time the act was done or the conduct was engaged in, was responsible for the internal management of the company; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there was no such director, any person who, at the time the act was done or the conduct was engaged in, was responsible under the immediate authority of the directors of the company for the internal management of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a partnership—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any partner in the partnership who, at the time the act was done or the conduct was engaged in, was responsible for the internal management of the partnership; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there was no such partner, any person who, at the time the act was done or the conduct was engaged in, was responsible under the immediate authority of the partners in the partnership for the internal management of the partnership; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of any other organization, any officer of the organization or other person who, at the time the act was done or the conduct was engaged in, was responsible for the internal management of the organization.

subsection.leadIn: A person charged with an offence under this Ordinance by virtue of subsection (1) is taken not to have done the act in question or not to have engaged in the conduct in question if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that he did not authorize the act to be done or the conduct to be engaged in; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Transactions relating to contravention not void or voidable
section.content: A transaction is not void or voidable by reason only that a contravention of any of the provisions of this Ordinance has taken place in relation to or as a result of the transaction.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Regulations

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes of any provision of this Ordinance that contemplates or authorizes the making of regulations with respect to any matter;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing for such matters as are necessary for giving full effect to the provisions of this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: generally for carrying out the purposes and provisions of this Ordinance.

schedule.name: sch1
schedule.heading: Exemptions

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Schedule—

def.name: SoundBroadcastingService
def.leadIn: sound broadcasting service (聲音廣播服務) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a service that includes broadcasting as defined in section 13A(1) of the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a service of a like nature;

def.name: TelevisionProgrammeService
def.leadIn: television programme service (電視節目服務) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a television programme service as defined in section 2(1) of the Broadcasting Ordinance (Cap. 562); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a service of a like nature.

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, the exemption of a matter from the application of Part 2 of this Ordinance (rules about sending commercial electronic messages) in accordance with Table 2 shall not be construed as implying that the other provisions of this Ordinance apply to that matter.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Exemptions

subsection.content: The matters described in an item in Table 1 are exempt from the application of this Ordinance.

The matters described in an item in column 1 in Table 2 are exempt from the application of Part 2 of this Ordinance (rules about sending commercial electronic messages) subject to the conditions, if any, specified in column 2 of that item.

schedule.crossHeading: Table 1Matters Exempted from Application of Ordinance

tr.td: Item
Description of exempt matter

Voice, sound, image or video messages, or messages combining text, voice, sound, images or video, that involve person-to-person interactive communications between a caller and a recipient without any pre-recorded or synthesized (machine-generated or simulated) element.
Voice, sound, image or video messages, or messages combining text, voice, sound, images or video, that involve—
a pre-recorded or synthesized (machine-generated or simulated) element,
whereby the pre-recorded or synthesized element is activated in response to information communicated by the caller.
Television programme services, whether or not licensed under the Broadcasting Ordinance (Cap. 562).
Sound broadcasting services, whether or not licensed under the Telecommunications Ordinance (Cap. 106).

text.b: Matters Exempted from Application of Part 2 of Ordinance

The exemption is subject to the condition that the commercial electronic message is sent to the person within a reasonable time after the information is communicated to the sender by that person.
the message is sent in response to information communicated to the sender by that person (including but not limited to information communicated through the Internet);
the information is communicated to the sender by that person either directly or in consequence of the conduct of that person;
the message is of a kind that the person would normally expect to receive as a result of the communication of that information.
Any electronic message the primary purpose of which is—
Not applicable.
to facilitate, complete or confirm a commercial transaction that the recipient has previously agreed to enter into with the sender;
to provide warranty information, product recall information or safety or security information with respect to a commercial product or service purchased or used by the recipient; or

to deliver goods or services, including product updates or upgrades, that the recipient is entitled to receive under the terms of a transaction that the recipient has previously agreed to enter into with the sender.
Any electronic message the primary purpose of which is to provide—
Not applicable.
at regular periodic intervals, account balance information or other type of account statement with respect to,
a subscription, membership, account, loan or comparable ongoing commercial relationship involving the ongoing purchase or use by the recipient of goods or services offered by the sender.

Any electronic message the primary purpose of which is to provide information directly related to an employment relationship or a related benefit plan in which the recipient is currently involved, participating or enrolled.
Not applicable.
